factoid: Kutúzov walked through the ranks.
Kutúzov sometimes stopped to say friendly words to officers he had known in the Turkish war.
Kutúzov sometimes stopped to say friendly words to soldiers.
Kutúzov looked at the boots of the soldiers.
Kutúzov shook his head sadly several times.
Kutúzov pointed the boots to the Austrian general.
The expression of Kutúzov seemed to say that he was not blaming anyone.
The expression of Kutúzov seemed to say that he could not help noticing a bad state of things.
The regimental commander ran forward each time Kutúzov pointed the boots.
The regimental commander feared missing a single word of the commander in chief regarding the regiment.
About twenty men of Kutúzov's suite followed behind him at a distance that allowed every softly spoken word to be heard.
The men of Kutúzov's suite talked among themselves.
The men of Kutúzov's suite sometimes laughed.
The nearest to the commander in chief walked a handsome adjutant.
That adjutant was Prince Bolkónski.
Beside Prince Bolkónski was his comrade Nesvítski.
Nesvítski was a tall staff officer.
Nesvítski was extremely stout.
Nesvítski had a kindly, smiling, handsome face.
Nesvítski had moist eyes.
Nesvítski could hardly keep from laughter.
The laughter of Nesvítski was provoked by a swarthy hussar officer who walked beside him.
The swarthy hussar officer had a grave face.
The swarthy hussar officer had no smile.
The swarthy hussar officer had no change in expression of his fixed eyes.
The swarthy hussar officer watched the regimental commander’s back.
The swarthy hussar officer mimicked the regimental commander’s every movement.
Each time the regimental commander started and bent forward, the swarthy hussar officer started and bent forward exactly the same manner.
Nesvítski laughed at the swarthy hussar officer’s mimicry.
Nesvítski nudged the others to look at the wag.
Kutúzov walked slowly and languidly past thousands of eyes.
The thousands of eyes were starting from their sockets to watch their chief.
On reaching the third company, Kutúzov suddenly stopped.
Kutúzov’s suite did not expect this and involuntarily came closer to him.
Kutúzov said “Ah, Timókhin!”.
Kutúzov recognized the red-nosed captain Timókhin.
Timókhin had been reprimanded on account of the blue greatcoat.
When the commander in chief addressed Timókhin, Timókhin drew himself up to such an extent that it seemed he could not have sustained it had the commander in chief continued to look at him.
Kutúzov understood Timókhin’s case and wished him nothing but good.
Kutúzov quickly turned away.
A scarcely perceptible smile flitted over Kutúzov’s scarred and puffy face.
Kutúzov said “Another Ismail comrade.”
Kutúzov said “A brave officer! Are you satisfied with him?”
Kutúzov asked the regimental commander if he was satisfied with Ismail.
The regimental commander answered “Highly satisfied, your excellency!”.
Kutúzov said “We all have our weaknesses.”
Kutúzov said “He used to have a predilection for Bacchus.”
The regimental commander was afraid he might be blamed for this.
The regimental commander did not answer.
The swarthy hussar officer noticed the face of the red-nosed captain and his drawn-in stomach.
The swarthy hussar officer mimicked the expression and pose of the red-nosed captain with such exactitude that Nesvítski laughed.
Kutúzov turned round.
The swarthy hussar officer had complete control of his face.
While Kutúzov was turning, the swarthy hussar officer made a grimace.
While Kutúzov was turning, the swarthy hussar officer assumed a most serious, deferential, and innocent expression.
The third company was the last.
Kutúzov pondered, apparently trying to recollect something.
Prince Andrew stepped forward from among the suite.
Prince Andrew said in French: “You told me to remind you of the officer Dólokhov, reduced to the ranks in this regiment.”
Kutúzov asked “Where is Dólokhov?”
Dólokhov had already changed into a soldier’s gray greatcoat.
Dólokhov did not wait to be called.
The shapely figure of the fair-haired soldier with clear blue eyes stepped forward from the ranks.
The fair-haired soldier went up to the commander in chief.
The fair-haired soldier presented arms to the commander in chief.
Kutúzov asked with a slight frown: “Have you a complaint to make?”
Prince Andrew said “This is Dólokhov.”
Kutúzov said “Ah!”.
Kutúzov said “I hope this will be a lesson to you.”
Kutúzov said “Do your duty.”
Kutúzov said “The Emperor is gracious, and I shan’t forget you if you deserve well.”
The clear blue eyes looked at the commander in chief just as boldly as they had looked at the regimental commander.
The clear blue eyes seemed by their expression to tear open the veil of convention that separates a commander in chief so widely from a private.
Dólokhov said in his firm, ringing, deliberate voice: “One thing I ask of your excellency.”
Dólokhov said: “I ask an opportunity to atone for my fault and prove my devotion to His Majesty the Emperor and to Russia.”
